There are ten kinds of equalities. If sentient beings possess these equalities, they will always receive excellent rewards while transmigrating and will quickly be able to enter the great city of fearlessness.

First, the equality of sentient beings;
Second, the equality of the Dharma;
Third, the equality of purity;
Fourth, the equality of giving;
Fifth, the equality of precepts;
Sixth, the equality of patience;

Tenth, the equality of the purity of all dharmas.
Virtuous ones!
What is the equality of sentient beings there?
Sentient beings refer to all sentient beings in the three realms.
If sentient beings love their own bodies, wish to obtain life, seek happiness and avoid suffering, they should study in this way:
If a person who lives and acts, whether good or bad, creates or instructs others to do so, they will experience the retribution in the present life.
Therefore, good people, if you seek happiness and avoid suffering, you should do this:

If you create good karma with body, speech, and mind and do not create evil karma, whether in this life or the next, you benefit yourself and others, do good for yourself and others, and do not create evil karma.
Good people, this is called the equality of sentient beings.
Good people!
What is the equality of the Dharma?

The Dharma is that if a sentient being seeks happiness and avoids suffering, rejoices in birth and fears death, is not separated from loved ones and does not meet with those they dislike, such a person's mind is drowned in the ocean.
Why is this?
If a sentient being clings to the self, they will transmigrate in birth and death, because they do not see the pure path of liberation.

Therefore, one should contemplate and observe the equality of dharmas, not apart from sentient beings there are dharmas, not apart from dharmas there are sentient beings. As the essential nature of sentient beings is precisely my essential nature, as my essential nature is precisely the essential nature of all dharmas, as the essential nature of all dharmas is precisely the essential nature of the Buddha's teachings.

When contemplating the equality of all dharmas in this way, sentient beings are unobtainable within the aggregates, unobtainable apart from the aggregates, unobtainable in their combination, and unobtainable apart from their combination. They are neither dharmas nor not dharmas.
This person thus abides in the absence of characteristics. This is called the equality of dharmas.
Good people!
What is purity and equality in them?
It means attaining a human body and fully possessing ten virtues.
What are the ten?
First, being free from low-class families;
Second, not being dull;
Third, not being mute;
Fourth, having complete faculties;
Fifth, attaining a male body;
Sixth, having a handsome appearance;
Seventh, having good relatives;
Eighth, not being poor;
Ninth, not being deceived by others, speaking with authority;
Tenth, being looked up to by many people.
Why is it said that attaining a human body is called pure equality?
Because by attaining a human body, one can obtain the three kinds of precepts, leave the three evil paths, and be able to seek the three vehicles and three kinds of enlightenment as one wishes.
What is pure equality?
If a person can attain enlightenment, their mind is not attached to any dharma, and their mind is not attached to any internal or external realm. Such a person does not rely on any dharma.
In suchness, they do not grasp at anything. Seeing all dharmas, they do not grasp at the internal mind or the external mind. In the two realms, they attain ultimate tranquility.

When this person thus contemplates the pure Dharma with right view, he does not see any sentient beings, life, longevity, birth, person, multitude, nurturer, doer, instigator, one who arises, one who causes arising, one who receives, one who causes receiving, one who knows, or one who sees, either internally or externally.

This person thus attains the pure equality of no-self in all sentient beings, with no sentient beings, no life, and no self. Free from desire and pure, he does not give rise to extreme views. Thus he enters the pure equality of all sentient beings. Thus he enters the wisdom seal of the emptiness and signlessness of all dharmas, and thus he enters the pure equality of all sentient beings.
This person, by that Dharma, matures sentient beings without destroying the self, and also without destroying phenomena or possessions.
If one knows the equality of the essence of all sentient beings, then one knows the equality of the essence of all dharmas.
If the essence of all dharmas is the essence of the Buddha's Dharma, this is called the equality of all dharmas and the Buddha's Dharma, and this is called pure equality.

If there are sentient beings who seek happiness, leave suffering, not be separated from loved ones, not encounter those they dislike, wish to have a long life, gain offerings, fame, wealth and nobility, and the five desires, they should study in this way:
Just as I love, desire, and cherish my own life without satiation, and protect it with all unsurpassed means without price;

In the same way, for all sentient beings, for each and every sentient being down to insects and ants, I love, desire, and cherish their lives without satiation, and protect them with all unsurpassed means without price.
Why do I harm and injure other sentient beings, other living creatures, take away their means of livelihood, deprive them of their lives, and destroy their lives?

If I cause harm and deprive other sentient beings, other living creatures, of their lives, for each and every life I deprive them of, I will in turn experience suffering for billions and trillions of eons in each and every life.

From today onwards, I will regard all sentient beings as my parents, children, and even insects and ants as my parents and children. I will no longer harm or injure other lives, nor will I deprive others of their means of livelihood, nor will I engage in activities that destroy life, nor will I instruct others to take away their vital energy or cut off their life force. In this way, I will transmigrate through birth and death for billions of eons, and in all my lifetimes, no one will be able to harm, injure, deprive, or destroy my life.
Why is this?
All sentient beings are none other than my parents, siblings, children, and so forth.

In this way, I have no sentient being who is not a parent, sibling, child, or so forth to me. For this reason, I have been close to all sentient beings, and all sentient beings have been close to me. If I were to harm those who have been close to me, this would be inappropriate.

For this reason, I will, due to this cause of contentment, even while wandering in cyclic existence, no longer consume tasteless, harmful food, but will possess great power, strong memory, a gentle mind, a good complexion, and be free from illness. This is called the means of livelihood.
What is the life of separation?

If one looks at sentient beings with an evil mind, exhales on their bodies, disturbs their minds, and takes away their vital energy from their limbs, because of taking away their vital energy, causing their body and mind to be afflicted by suffering, one should study like this:

What is the life of destruction?
If sentient beings, for their own food, cut off limbs and joints, completely deprive them of vitality, push them from high places, deep water, or great rivers, or give them poison to revive corpses.
If they create spells or other harmful things, cut off their food and drink, or behead them to sever their life roots.
For these reasons, if you love yourselves and wish for long life, seek happiness and avoid suffering, fame, wealth, and nobility, and seek liberation, you should study thus:
I am close to all sentient beings, and all sentient beings are close to me.
If I deprive them of vitality and cut off their limbs and joints for my own food, up to beheading them, this is not right.
For these reasons, even in the time of transmigration, there will be no one who can behead me or destroy my life. This is called destroying life, and this is pure equality.

This is called the purity and equality of the world.

There are ten kinds of equanimity. If sentient beings possess these ten equalities, they will always receive excellent rewards in saá¹ƒsÄra and quickly be able to enter the great city of fearlessness.
What are the ten?
First, the equality of sentient beings;
Second, the equality of the Dharma;
Third, the equality of purity;
Fourth, the equality of giving;
Fifth, the equality of precepts;
Sixth, the equality of patience;
Seventh, the equality of diligence;
Eighth, the equality of meditation;
Ninth, the equality of wisdom;
Tenth, the equality of the purity of all dharmas.
Good people!
What is the equality of sentient beings?
If sentient beings seek to receive a body and life, to seek pleasure and avoid suffering, they should have this view:
If the recipient creates karma, whether good or bad, with body, speech, or mind, whether they do it themselves or tell others to do it, they will receive the retribution in this life or the next.
Therefore, if you want to avoid suffering and seek happiness in the two worlds, you should create good with body, speech, and mind, and do not give rise to evil.
If you seek to benefit yourself and others in both this and future lives, to bring happiness to yourself and others, and to make yourself and others good, do not do evil.
This is the equality of all beings.
Good people!
What is the equality of the Dharma?

If there are beings who seek happiness, leave suffering, delight in birth and fear death, are not separated from loved ones, and do not meet with those they dislike, the ocean of their minds is drowned.
Why is this?
If there are beings who cling to the self, they will transmigrate in birth and death, and will not see the pure path of liberation.

Therefore, contemplate and observe the equality of the Dharma. Beings are not apart from the Dharma, and the Dharma is not apart from beings. If the essential nature of beings is the essential nature of the self, and the essential nature of the self is the essential nature of all dharmas, and the essential nature of all dharmas is the essential nature of the Buddha's Dharma,

If one contemplates the equality of all phenomena in this way, one attains the absence of anything, does not see sentient beings, and also does not see the coming and going, aggregation and dispersion of sentient beings, and also does not see any sentient beings to be attained. It is neither Dharma nor non-Dharma. This person thus attains abiding in the absence of characteristics, which is the equality of Dharma.
Virtuous ones!
What is the equality of purity there?
It means attaining a human body and fully possessing ten virtues.
What are the ten?
First, being free from low-class families;
Second, not being dull;
Third, not being mute;
Fourth, not having incomplete faculties;
Fifth, attaining a male body;
Sixth, having a handsome appearance and obtaining good relatives;
Seventh, not being poor;
Eighth, not being deceived by others;
Ninth, having a moderate voice when speaking;
Tenth, being liked by many people.
Why is it said to attain the equality of purity in a human body?

Just as obtaining a human body, obtaining the three types of precepts, leaving the three evil paths, and being able to seek the three vehicles, with this one can attain the three kinds of enlightenment, not by other methods.
How can pure equality reach enlightenment?

This person causes the mind not to rely on any dharmas, causes the mind not to rely on internal and external objects, does not rely on suchness to see, all dharmas have no combined characteristics, does not grasp the internal mind, does not grasp the external mind, and attains extreme tranquility in the two objects.

In this way, when the principle of pure right view is seen, one does not see that internally there is a self or sentient beings, externally there is a life, a lifespan, one who is born, a person, a multitude, one who is nurtured, an agent, one who causes action, one who arises, one who causes arising, one who receives, one who causes receiving, one who knows, or one who sees. These sixteen names all come from false imagination.
This person, in this way, attains the pure equality of seeing no self in all sentient beings. For this reason, one leaves desire and is pure, not giving rise to extreme views.
In this way, one enters the equality and purity of sentient beings, and the wisdom seal of the emptiness of phenomena, without characteristics or aspirations.
In this way, having entered the equality and purity of sentient beings, one further uses those dharmas to bring sentient beings to maturity, without destroying oneself or one's wealth.
If one knows the equality of the essential nature of sentient beings, then one knows the equality of the essential nature of all dharmas.

If the essential nature of all dharmas is equality, then that is the equality of the essential nature of the Buddha's teachings. Therefore, all dharmas are called the Buddha's teachings, and this is purity and equality.
Good people!
What is the purity and equality of giving there?
It is giving with the purity of the four kinds of minds.
Because of giving, sentient beings, while transmigrating, always receive excellent rewards and are able to quickly enter the great city of fearlessness.
What are the four?
First, giving rise to a compassionate mind towards all sentient beings;
second, an impartial mind;
Third, the mind of great kindness;
Fourth, the mind of great compassion.

As for the pure and impartial mind of compassion, if there are sentient beings who seek happiness and freedom from suffering, who wish to be with loved ones and not be separated from them, who wish to avoid encountering those they dislike, who wish for a long life, benefits, fame, and a good reputation, and who wish to enjoy the five desires of the wealthy and noble, they should study as follows:
Just as I delight in and love my own body and life, and protect them with all the unsurpassed means, without any price or measure,

In the same way, towards all sentient beings, each and every sentient being, down to insects and ants, I also delight in and love their own bodies and lives, and protect them with all the unsurpassed means, without any price or measure.

If I harm sentient beings, or if I deprive them of the means of livelihood and cut off their life force, I will, in the course of hundreds of thousands of lives in the cycle of birth and death, be harmed in return, lose the means of livelihood, and have my life force cut off, experiencing immeasurable suffering.

From today onwards, I will regard all sentient beings as my parents, children, and grandchildren, even insects and ants, as my parents and children. Therefore, I will no longer harm sentient beings, nor will I deprive them of their means of livelihood or take their lives, nor will I instruct others to do so.
In this way, I will be able to transmigrate through birth and death for billions of eons without being harmed, nor will I be deprived of my means of livelihood or have my life taken.
Why is this?
No sentient being is not my parent, brother, or child. In this way, for all sentient beings, there is not a single sentient being who is not my parent, brother, or child.

For this reason, I have never not been a relative of all sentient beings, and all sentient beings have also never not been my relatives. If one causes harm to one's parents up to one's children and spouse, this is not reasonable.
Good people!
What is it that is not causing harm?
If sentient beings seek happiness and leave suffering, they should study like this:

If I cause harm to the mind of a ká¹£atriya, causing that ká¹£atriya to not give rise to joy and delight towards his own realm, country, and people, and also cause harm to the mind of a brÄhman up to an animal, causing him to not give rise to joy and delight towards what he originally desired,
for this reason they will attack each other in succession, fight and quarrel, flatter and lie, harm each other, and cut off each other's life roots.

For this reason, I will from today cease to harm and take the lives of sentient beings. By the cause and condition of this pure and equal giving of Dharma, I will for a long time in the flow of birth and death, be unable to be touched, disturbed, quarreled with, litigated, or have my life taken.
For this reason, it is called 'not touching harm.'
Good people!
What is it that does not harm life among them?
If sentient beings seek life and do not harm, they should study thus:

All sentient beings are none other than my relatives. If I were to rain violently or at the wrong time, or rain ashes and dust causing much darkness and gloom, or have a long drought drying up flowing water, causing the flowers, fruits, medicines, grains, and various flavors to be damaged, by this cause and condition, it would cause my relatives to suffer from hunger and hardship, move their four elements, give rise to various illnesses, and even end their lives.
If one adds this harm, it is not reasonable.

For this reason, I refrain from harming living beings, so as not to cause harm to the essence and vitality of the earth, to ensure that my relatives and I do not suffer from famine, and to prevent various illnesses and untimely death caused by the disturbance of the four elements.

By this pure and equal giving, even in the long-lasting cycle of birth and death, I do not experience the suffering of hunger, disease, and death. For this reason, it is called refraining from harming life.
Good people!
What is it that does not deprive others of the means of livelihood?
If sentient beings seek to preserve their lives, they should study in this way:

All sentient beings are my relatives. If I deprive them of the means of livelihood such as flowers, fruits, herbs, and the essence of the five grains, those sentient beings, if they eat those things lacking in good essence, flowers, fruits, herbs, and the taste of the five grains, will become emaciated, weak, and lose their strength, become forgetful, ill-tempered, restless, coarse, pale, and give rise to various illnesses.
If one adds this suffering, this is not reasonable.

Therefore, I should accept the teachings of the sages and gods of the past. Among the various flavors, I should only take one sixty-fourth part of the essence to sustain my body and life. I will keep sixty-three parts of the essence of the earth's sap to nourish beings and let them experience peace and joy.
Because of the causes and conditions of my contented actions, I will, for a long time, revolve in the flow of birth and death, and will not eat again the food that lacks good flavor and essence.

Because of that food, I will be endowed with majestic virtue and strength, able to strongly remember, my mind nature will be gentle, my facial appearance upright, and I will be free from various illnesses and suffering.
This is called not depriving the means of sustaining life.
Good people!
What is it among them that is not being separated from life?
If one seeks life, one should study like this:

All sentient beings are my relatives. If I were to harm them with an evil mind, even by a mere glance or a breath that causes them to lose their mind, or if I were to deprive them of their vital energy from their limbs and joints, causing my relatives to suffer physically and mentally, this would be unreasonable.

For this reason, I should not allow non-humans to harm me for a long time as I transmigrate through birth and death. They should not breathe on me, glance at me, disturb my mind, or deprive me of my vital energy. For this reason, it is called 'not being separated from life.'
Good people!
What is meant by 'intact life' there?
If sentient beings love their own lives and seek happiness and avoid suffering, fame, wealth, and status, up to liberation, they should study in this way:

All sentient beings are my relatives. If I were to deprive my relatives of their essence and vitality for the sake of food and drink, or if I were to dismember them limb by limb, or push them off a mountain, a tree, a high building, or a deep river, or give them poison, or send them to be killed by a zombie or an evil spirit, or curse them, or deprive them of food and drink, or cut off their heads with a sword, or deprive them of their life force by any means, or inflict such suffering upon them, it would be unreasonable.

For this reason, for a long time in the cycle of birth and death, sentient beings have not deprived me of my essence and vitality, nor have they been able to dismember me or deprive me of my life force. For this reason, it is called indestructible life. This is the purity and equality of giving.

Furthermore, the purity and equality of giving means that out of compassion for all sentient beings, one accumulates merit and wisdom for them, removes illusory views, and perseveres firmly. One seeks all goodness and practices as taught, and does not give rise to evil thoughts for the sake of livelihood.
They do not harbor harmful intentions towards sentient beings, and the precepts they uphold are the same as those of sentient beings. Seeing the joy of sentient beings, they deeply rejoice.
They are able to be content with their own circumstances of happiness, and they are able to let go of all things they hold dear.

They have no stingy thoughts towards superior dharmas, and they are always fearful of the three realms. They have mastery over the power of patience, and they believe in the characteristics of impermanence and practice accordingly.

They are able to observe their own faults and shortcomings, and when they see the faults and shortcomings of others, they give rise to compassion. They cultivate goodness without weariness and diligently repent of their faults. They aspire to boundless [virtue] and joyfully seek the correct principles. They always think of sentient beings as being like fields of blessings, and they diligently work for sentient beings to put an end to the evil destinies.
Their minds do not dwell on any dharmas. This is the purity and equality of giving in the conventional truth.
I will now explain the purity and equality of giving in the ultimate truth.

Namely, the ten wholesome courses of action, which are to refrain from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, frivolous speech, greed, hatred, and wrong views.
Good people!
Due to refraining from killing, one obtains ten kinds of merits.
What are the ten?
First, one attains great fearlessness towards all beings;
Second, one attains a great compassionate mind towards all beings;
Third, one attains the severing of habitual tendencies;
Fourth, one is free from various illnesses and afflictions;
Fifth, one attains a long lifespan;
Sixth, one is protected by non-humans;
Seventh, one sleeps and wakes peacefully without any bad dreams;
Eighth, one has no enemies;
Ninth, one is not afraid of evil paths;
Tenth, one attains rebirth in a good realm of existence.
By dedicating the wholesome roots of refraining from killing to supreme, perfect enlightenment, this person will soon realize the unsurpassed wisdom.
Having attained enlightenment, in that buddha land, beings who are free from harm and killing and have long lives will be reborn in that country.
Good people!
In that place, by the causes and conditions of refraining from stealing, ten kinds of merits are obtained.
What are the ten?
First, one will be endowed with great wealth;
second, one will not share it with others;
third, one will not share it with the five families;
fourth, many people will love and respect one, never abandoning one;
fifth, traveling far to the ten directions, one will have no worries;
sixth, one will be fearless in one's activities;
seventh, one will always enjoy giving;
eighth, without seeking wealth and treasures, one will quickly obtain them naturally;
ninth, having obtained wealth, one will immediately give it away;
tenth, one will be reborn in a good realm.

Using this wholesome root of refraining from stealing to turn toward supreme, perfect enlightenment, after attaining enlightenment, in that buddha land, it will be replete with various flowers, fruit trees, forests, clothing, necklaces, adornments, and precious treasures, all of which will be completely filled.
Good people!
In refraining from sexual misconduct, ten kinds of merits are obtained.
What are the ten?
First, one obtains the discipline of controlling the senses;
second, one abides in the pure liberation of desire;
third, one does not trouble others;
fourth, many people praise one;
fifth, many people enjoy seeing one;
sixth, one is able to arouse diligence;
seventh, one sees the faults of birth and death;
eighth, one always enjoys giving;
ninth, one always enjoys seeking the Dharma;
tenth, one obtains rebirth in a good realm.

Using the wholesome roots of abstaining from sexual misconduct to turn toward supreme, perfect enlightenment, once they attain enlightenment, in their buddha lands there will be no foul smells, no women, and no one will engage in sexual desire, all being born through transformation.
Good people!
Abstaining from false speech has ten kinds of merits.
What are the ten?
First, the words of many people are trusted;
Second, in all places, up to the heavens, one's speech is effective;
Third, the mouth emits a fragrance like an utpala flower;
Fourth, one alone serves as a witness among the assemblies of humans and gods;
Fifth, many people love and respect one, free from all doubts;
Sixth, one always speaks the truth;
Seventh, the mind and thoughts are pure;
Eighth, one is always without flattery, and one's speech is timely;
Ninth, one is always full of joy;
Tenth, one is reborn in a good realm.

With these wholesome roots of refraining from false speech, they dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment, and when they attain enlightenment, in that buddha land there will be no foul smells, but various wonderful fragrances will fill everywhere.
Good people!
In refraining from the causes and conditions of divisive speech, they attain ten kinds of merits.
What are the ten?
First, they attain an indestructible body;
second, they attain indestructible retinue;
third, they attain indestructible friendships;
fourth, they attain indestructible faith;
fifth, they attain indestructible Dharma;
sixth, they attain indestructible precepts;
seventh, they attain indestructible samÄdhi;
eighth, they attain indestructible samÄdhi;
ninth, they attain indestructible patience;

With these wholesome roots of refraining from divisive speech, they dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment, and when they attain enlightenment, the retinue of beings in that buddha land will not be destroyed by demons or others.

With these wholesome roots of refraining from harsh speech, they dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment, and after attaining enlightenment, the Dharma sound fills their buddha-lands, far removed from all vulgar and evil words.
Good people!
In refraining from frivolous speech, they attain ten kinds of merits.
What are the ten?
First, devas and humans love and respect them;
second, devas and humans follow and rejoice in praising them;
third, they always delight in truthful speech;

By dedicating the wholesome roots of abandoning frivolous speech towards supreme perfect enlightenment, after attaining enlightenment, in that buddha land, those who have a pleasant appearance, a strong memory, and enjoy solitude will be reborn in that land.
All of you!
In that abandonment of greed, ten kinds of merits are obtained.
What are the ten?
First, the sense faculties are not deficient;
Second, the verbal actions are pure;
Third, the mind is not distracted;
Fourth, one obtains superior rewards;
Fifth, one obtains great wealth and nobility;
Sixth, many people enjoy watching;
Seventh, one obtains indestructible retinue and indestructible wealth;
Eighth, one always meets with wise people;
Ninth, one does not leave the sound of the Dharma;
Tenth, one obtains rebirth in a good realm.

Using this wholesome root of detachment from desire, they dedicate it to supreme, perfect enlightenment. Having attained enlightenment, in their buddha-lands they are free from the demons, enemies, and non-Buddhist paths.
Good people!
In that detachment from anger, ten kinds of merits are obtained.

First, one attains freedom from anger;
second, one does not enjoy accumulating wealth;
third, one accords with the sages;
fourth, one always associates with the sages;

Seventh, seeing sentient beings happy, one gives rise to joy;

All of you!
Being free from wrong views has ten kinds of merits.

Second, one believes in karmic retribution and does not commit evil even if one's life is at stake;
Third, one takes refuge in the Three Jewels and does not believe in celestial spirits;
Fourth, one attains right views and does not choose auspicious years, months, days, or times;
Fifth, one is always born among humans and gods and leaves the evil paths;
Sixth, one attains a virtuous mind and is praised by the wise;
Seventh, one abandons worldly affairs and always seeks the noble path;
Eighth, one leaves the views of annihilation and permanence and believes in the Dharma of causes and conditions;
Ninth, they will always encounter those with correct faith, correct practice, and correct aspiration;
Tenth, they will be reborn in a good realm.

By dedicating the wholesome roots of abandoning wrong views to supreme, perfect enlightenment, this person will quickly fulfill the six perfections and attain perfect enlightenment in a pure buddha land.

Having attained enlightenment, in that buddha land, sentient beings adorned with all wholesome roots of merit and wisdom will be reborn in that land. They will not believe in celestial spirits and will be free from the fear of evil realms. When their lives end there, they will be reborn again in a good realm.
Good people!
When practicing the equality of pure giving, practice the equality of abstaining from killing in precepts.
By this cause and condition, one will be endowed with great rewards and be free from all fears.
Good people!
When practicing the equality of pure giving, practice the equality of abstaining from stealing in precepts.
For these causes and conditions, one will be endowed with great fruits and rewards that are not shared by others, and the cultivation of all wholesome deeds will be unobstructed.
Good people!
When practicing giving purely and equally, one should practice precepts and distance oneself from sexual misconduct equally.

For these causes and conditions, one will be endowed with great fruits and rewards in cultivating wholesome roots, without obstruction, and without thoughts of sexual misconduct, observing oneself and others.
Good people!
When practicing giving purely and equally, one should practice precepts and distance oneself from false speech equally.

For these causes and conditions, one will be endowed with great fruits and rewards. If one is slandered and not believed, one will practice as taught, and whatever one sets out to do will be firm. One will be the sole witness among the multitudes of gods and humans, and the mouth will emit a fragrance like an utpala flower.
Good people!
When practicing giving purely and equally, one should practice precepts and distance oneself from divisive speech equally.
For these causes and conditions, they will attain great rewards, an indestructible retinue, a retinue of true men, and a retinue of respectful faith.
Good people!
When practicing giving purely and equally, one should practice precepts and distance oneself from evil speech equally.
For these causes and conditions, one will attain great rewards, be free from harsh speech, obtain a subtle voice, be endowed with purity, and be free from foul sounds.
Good people!
When practicing giving purely and equally, one should practice precepts and distance oneself from frivolous speech equally.
For these causes and conditions, one will attain great rewards, speak with authority, resolve the doubts of the great assembly, and be enjoyed by the masses.
Good people!
When practicing giving purely and equally, one should practice precepts and distance oneself from covetousness equally.
For these causes and conditions, one will attain great rewards, be able to give up what one has received, and fully receive supreme rewards and great power.
Good people!
When practicing the equality of pure giving, one should also practice the equality of non-anger in precepts.
By these causes and conditions, one will attain great rewards, be upright and prosperous, be loved and respected by many, be unobstructed, and have complete faculties.
Good people!
When practicing the equality of pure giving, one should also practice the equality of non-wrong views in precepts.

By these causes and conditions, one will attain great rewards, be born in a country with right views and a family with right views, always encounter Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Sravakas, and Pratyekabuddhas, see the Buddha, hear the Dharma, make offerings to the Sangha, cultivate Bodhisattva practices, and always not abandon pure equality.
Good people!

This is the purity and equality of the practice of precepts. Those who adorn themselves with this practice of precepts will soon be endowed with the major and minor marks, accomplish the pure sound of the Buddha's merits, subdue the demons and enemies, and purify the practice of meditation, mindfulness, wisdom, and great compassion, and even be able to accomplish the purity and equality of all the Buddha's teachings. This is the purity and equality of the practice of precepts that arises in the world.
Good people!
